0.text: Network Working Group                                       L. Masinter

1.text: Request for Comments: 2324                                 1 April 1998

2.text: Category: Informational

0.text: Hyper Text Coffee Pot Control Protocol (HTCPCP/1.0)
Status of this Memo
This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does

1.text: not specify an Internet standard of any kind.  Distribution of this

2.text: memo is unlimited.

0.text: Copyright Notice
Copyright (C) The Internet Society (1998).  All Rights Reserved.
Abstract
This document describes HTCPCP, a protocol for controlling,

1.text: monitoring, and diagnosing coffee pots.

0.text: 1. Rationale and Scope
There is coffee all over the world. Increasingly, in a world in which

1.text: computing is ubiquitous, the computists want to make coffee. Coffee

2.text: brewing is an art, but the distributed intelligence of the web-

3.text: connected world transcends art.  Thus, there is a strong, dark, rich

4.text: requirement for a protocol designed espressoly for the brewing of

5.text: coffee. Coffee is brewed using coffee pots.  Networked coffee pots

6.text: require a control protocol if they are to be controlled.

0.text: Increasingly, home and consumer devices are being connected to the

1.text: Internet. Early networking experiments demonstrated vending devices

2.text: connected to the Internet for status monitoring [COKE]. One of the

3.text: first remotely _operated_ machine to be hooked up to the Internet,

4.text: the Internet Toaster, (controlled via SNMP) was debuted in 1990

0.text: The demand for ubiquitous appliance connectivity that is causing the

1.text: consumption of the IPv4 address space. Consumers want remote control

2.text: of devices such as coffee pots so that they may wake up to freshly

3.text: brewed coffee, or cause coffee to be prepared at a precise time after

4.text: the completion of dinner preparations.

0.text: Masinter                     Informational                      [Page 1]
RFC 2324                       HTCPCP/1.0                   1 April 1998
This document specifies a Hyper Text Coffee Pot Control Protocol

1.text: (HTCPCP), which permits the full request and responses necessary to

2.text: control all devices capable of making the popular caffeinated hot

3.text: beverages.

0.text: HTTP 1.1 ([RFC2068]) permits the transfer of web objects from origin

1.text: servers to clients. The web is world-wide.  HTCPCP is based on HTTP.

2.text: This is because HTTP is everywhere. It could not be so pervasive

3.text: without being good. Therefore, HTTP is good. If you want good coffee,

4.text: HTCPCP needs to be good. To make HTCPCP good, it is good to base

0.text: Future versions of this protocol may include extensions for espresso

1.text: machines and similar devices.

0.text: 2. HTCPCP Protocol
The HTCPCP protocol is built on top of HTTP, with the addition of a

1.text: few new methods, header fields and return codes.  All HTCPCP servers

2.text: should be referred to with the "coffee:" URI scheme (Section 4).

0.text: 2.1 HTCPCP Added Methods
2.1.1 The BREW method, and the use of POST
Commands to control a coffee pot are sent from client to coffee

1.text: server using either the BREW or POST method, and a message body with

2.text: Content-Type set to "application/coffee-pot-command".

0.text: A coffee pot server MUST accept both the BREW and POST method

1.text: equivalently.  However, the use of POST for causing actions to happen

2.text: is deprecated.

0.text: Coffee pots heat water using electronic mechanisms, so there is no

1.text: fire. Thus, no firewalls are necessary, and firewall control policy

2.text: is irrelevant. However, POST may be a trademark for coffee, and so

3.text: the BREW method has been added. The BREW method may be used with

4.text: other HTTP-based protocols (e.g., the Hyper Text Brewery Control

0.text: 2.1.2 GET method
In HTTP, the GET method is used to mean "retrieve whatever

1.text: information (in the form of an entity) identified by the Request-

2.text: URI." If the Request-URI refers to a data-producing process, it is

3.text: the produced data which shall be returned as the entity in the

4.text: response and not the source text of the process, unless that text

5.text: happens to be the output of the process.

0.text: Masinter                     Informational                      [Page 2]
RFC 2324                       HTCPCP/1.0                   1 April 1998
In HTCPCP, the resources associated with a coffee pot are physical,

1.text: and not information resources. The "data" for most coffee URIs

2.text: contain no caffeine.

0.text: 2.1.3 PROPFIND method
If a cup of coffee is data, metadata about the brewed resource is

1.text: discovered using the PROPFIND method [WEBDAV].

0.text: 2.1.4 WHEN method
When coffee is poured, and milk is offered, it is necessary for the

1.text: holder of the recipient of milk to say "when" at the time when

2.text: sufficient milk has been introduced into the coffee. For this

3.text: purpose, the "WHEN" method has been added to HTCPCP. Enough? Say

4.text: WHEN.

0.text: 2.2 Coffee Pot Header fields
HTCPCP recommends several HTTP header fields and defines some new

1.text: ones.

0.text: 2.2.1 Recommended header fields
2.2.1.1 The "safe" response header field.
[SAFE] defines a HTTP response header field, "Safe", which can be

1.text: used to indicate that repeating a HTTP request is safe. The inclusion

2.text: of a "Safe: Yes" header field allows a client to repeat a previous

3.text: request if the result of the request might be repeated.

0.text: The actual safety of devices for brewing coffee varies widely, and

1.text: may depend, in fact, on conditions in the client rather than just in

2.text: the server. Thus, this protocol includes an extension to the "Safe"

3.text: response header:

0.text: Safe                = "Safe" ":" safe-nature

1.text: safe-nature         = "yes" | "no" | conditionally-safe

2.text: conditionally-safe  = "if-" safe-condition

3.text: safe-condition      = "user-awake" | token

0.text: indication will allow user agents to handle retries of some safe

1.text: requests, in particular safe POST requests, in a more user-friendly

2.text: way.

0.text: Masinter                     Informational                      [Page 3]
RFC 2324                       HTCPCP/1.0                   1 April 1998
2.2.2 New header fields
2.2.2.1 The Accept-Additions header field
In HTTP, the "Accept" request-header field is used to specify media

1.text: types which are acceptable for the response. However, in HTCPCP, the

2.text: response may result in additional actions on the part of the

3.text: automated pot. For this reason, HTCPCP adds a new header field,

4.text: "Accept-Additions":

0.text: Accept-Additions = "Accept-Additions" ":"

1.text: #( addition-range [ accept-params ] )

0.text: addition-type   = ( "*"

1.text: | milk-type

2.text: | syrup-type

3.text: | sweetener-type

4.text: | spice-type

0.text: 2.2.3 Omitted Header Fields
No options were given for decaffeinated coffee. What's the point?
2.3 HTCPCP return codes
Normal HTTP return codes are used to indicate difficulties of the

1.text: HTCPCP server. This section identifies special interpretations and

2.text: new return codes.

0.text: 2.3.1 406 Not Acceptable
This return code is normally interpreted as "The resource identified

1.text: by the request is only capable of generating response entities which

2.text: have content characteristics not acceptable according to the accept

3.text: headers sent in the request. In HTCPCP, this response code MAY be

4.text: returned if the operator of the coffee pot cannot comply with the

5.text: Accept-Addition request. Unless the request was a HEAD request, the

6.text: response SHOULD include an entity containing a list of available

0.text: Masinter                     Informational                      [Page 4]
RFC 2324                       HTCPCP/1.0                   1 April 1998
In practice, most automated coffee pots cannot currently provide

1.text: additions.

0.text: 2.3.2 418 I'm a teapot
Any attempt to brew coffee with a teapot should result in the error

1.text: code "418 I'm a teapot". The resulting entity body MAY be short and

2.text: stout.

0.text: 3. The "coffee" URI scheme
Because coffee is international, there are international coffee URI

1.text: schemes.  All coffee URL schemes are written with URL encoding of the

2.text: UTF-8 encoding of the characters that spell the word for "coffee" in

3.text: any of 29 languages, following the conventions for

4.text: internationalization in URIs [URLI18N].

0.text: coffee-url  =  coffee-scheme ":" [ "//" host ]

1.text: ["/" pot-designator ] ["?" additions-list ]

0.text: coffee-scheme = ( "koffie"                      ; Afrikaans, Dutch

1.text: | "q%C3%A6hv%C3%A6"          ; Azerbaijani

3.text: | "akeita"                   ; Basque

4.text: | "koffee"                   ; Bengali

0.text: pot-designator = "pot-" integer  ; for machines with multiple pots

1.text: additions-list = #( addition )

0.text: Masinter                     Informational                      [Page 5]
RFC 2324                       HTCPCP/1.0                   1 April 1998
All alternative coffee-scheme forms are equivalent.  However, the use

1.text: of coffee-scheme in various languages MAY be interpreted as an

2.text: indication of the kind of coffee produced by the coffee pot.  Note

3.text: that while URL scheme names are case-independent, capitalization is

4.text: important for German and thus the initial "K" must be encoded.

0.text: 4. The "message/coffeepot" media type
The entity body of a POST or BREW request MUST be of Content-Type

1.text: "message/coffeepot". Since most of the information for controlling

2.text: the coffee pot is conveyed by the additional headers, the content of

3.text: "message/coffeepot" contains only a coffee-message-body:

0.text: coffee-message-body = "start" | "stop"
5. Operational constraints
This section lays out some of the operational issues with deployment

1.text: of HTCPCP ubiquitously.

0.text: 5.1 Timing Considerations
A robust quality of service is required between the coffee pot user

1.text: and the coffee pot service.  Coffee pots SHOULD use the Network Time

2.text: Protocol [NTP] to synchronize their clocks to a globally accurate

3.text: time standard.

0.text: Telerobotics has been an expensive technology. However, with the

1.text: advent of the Cambridge Coffee Pot [CAM], the use of the web (rather

2.text: than SNMP) for remote system monitoring and management has been

3.text: proven.  Additional coffee pot maintenance tasks might be

4.text: accomplished by remote robotics.

0.text: Web data is normally static. Therefore to save data transmission and

1.text: time, Web browser programs store each Web page retrieved by a user on

2.text: the user's computer. Thus, if the user wants to return to that page,

3.text: it is now stored locally and does not need to be requested again from

4.text: the server. An image used for robot control or for monitoring a

5.text: changing scene is dynamic. A fresh version needs to be retrieved from

6.text: the server each time it is accessed.

0.text: 5.2 Crossing firewalls
In most organizations HTTP traffic crosses firewalls fairly easily.

1.text: Modern coffee pots do not use fire. However, a "firewall" is useful

2.text: for protection of any source from any manner of heat, and not just

3.text: fire. Every home computer network SHOULD be protected by a firewall

4.text: from sources of heat. However, remote control of coffee pots is

0.text: Masinter                     Informational                      [Page 6]
RFC 2324                       HTCPCP/1.0                   1 April 1998
important from outside the home. Thus, it is important that HTCPCP

1.text: cross firewalls easily.

0.text: By basing HTCPCP on HTTP and using port 80, it will get all of HTTP's

1.text: firewall-crossing virtues. Of course, the home firewalls will require

2.text: reconfiguration or new versions in order to accommodate HTCPCP-

3.text: specific methods, headers and trailers, but such upgrades will be

4.text: easily accommodated. Most home network system administrators drink

5.text: coffee, and are willing to accommodate the needs of tunnelling

0.text: 6. System management considerations
Coffee pot monitoring using HTTP protocols has been an early

1.text: application of the web.  In the earliest instance, coffee pot

2.text: monitoring was an early (and appropriate) use of ATM networks [CAM].

0.text: The traditional technique [CAM] was to attach a frame-grabber to a

1.text: video camera, and feed the images to a web server. This was an

2.text: appropriate application of ATM networks. In this coffee pot

3.text: installation, the Trojan Room of Cambridge University laboratories

4.text: was used to give a web interface to monitor a common coffee pot.  of

5.text: us involved in related research and, being poor, impoverished

6.text: academics, we only had one coffee filter machine between us, which

7.text: lived in the corridor just outside the Trojan Room. However, being

8.text: highly dedicated and hard-working academics, we got through a lot of

9.text: coffee, and when a fresh pot was brewed, it often didn't last long.

0.text: This service was created as the first application to use a new RPC

1.text: mechanism designed in the Cambridge Computer Laboratory - MSRPC2. It

2.text: runs over MSNL (Multi-Service Network Layer) - a network layer

3.text: protocol designed for ATM networks.

0.text: Coffee pots on the Internet may be managed using the Coffee Pot MIB

1.text: [CPMIB].

0.text: 7. Security Considerations
Anyone who gets in between me and my morning coffee should be

1.text: insecure.

0.text: Unmoderated access to unprotected coffee pots from Internet users

1.text: might lead to several kinds of "denial of coffee service" attacks.

2.text: The improper use of filtration devices might admit trojan grounds.

3.text: Filtration is not a good virus protection method.

0.text: Masinter                     Informational                      [Page 7]
RFC 2324                       HTCPCP/1.0                   1 April 1998
Putting coffee grounds into Internet plumbing may result in clogged

1.text: plumbing, which would entail the services of an Internet Plumber

2.text: [PLUMB], who would, in turn, require an Internet Plumber's Helper.

0.text: Access authentication will be discussed in a separate memo.
